description.narrative: Sensing and exploring activities to unpack each focus area and to identify where it can bring in the most added value by acceleration of learning and infusing new approaches and solutions.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

comment.narrative:
1.1 5 new sources of data per year 1.2 6 different type of data sources per year 1.3 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 5 innovation methods per Action Plan
2.1 6 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 2 lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network: 48 interaction per year. 3.2 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1. - 5 new data sources - Target 1 is met. 1) PPE Disposal Survey & PPE Containers Usage Stats; 2) #GreenAralSea SM Impressions & Engagement Data; 3) Telegram based surveys of business community on COVID impact 1.2. - 4 different types of data sources - 1) Process monitoring data; 2) Social media data and 3) Financial transaction data. 1.3. 132 new solutions - 1) Open call for ideas – 20 proposals; 2) COVID-19 Challenge 2020 – 110 solutions (12 semi-finalists and 5 finalists; 3) PPE Waste Management – 2 solutions; 1.4. - 10 methods. • Social media analysis, • Foresight, • Sensemaking, • Horizon scanning, • Minimal Viable Product (MVP), • Crowdsourcing, • Online challenges, • Assess mapping, • Crowdfunding,• Solutions Mapping
2.1. 4 blogs and 3 videos produced; 2.2. 2 processes are taken up by the government partners: 1) Online challenges/hackathons and 2)Crowdfunding instruments and methods; 2.3. 4 government partners learned about crowdfunding instrument via partnership formalized by MOU 2.4. Target achieved - Providing inputs in UNDP Portfolio Sensemaking, CPD, UNDAF and new proposal discussions
3.1. 48 - Lab should interacted at least once a week with another lab, a partner, and the global team. 3.2. Lab shared insights via blogs and social media posts. Information shared: Crowdfunding experience at UNDP IRH Crowdfunding Academy, Crowdfunding experience through calls/interaction with UNDP CO in Kosovo, Columbia AccLab, Medical Waste Initiative experience with UNDP CO in Armenia and Malawi AccLab 3.3. Done on a regular basis 3.4. Blogs are published on CO website. Regular updates are provided on social media - Facebook, Twitter
Initial 100 day plan was developed and followed up. Second 100 day plan was developed and recorded by AccLab global team, which included plans to address 2 development challenges – single use plastic waste and improving efficiency of public service delivery in rural areas. Due to pandemic, single use plastic waste was replaced by addressing the challenge of proper management of Personal Protection Equipment (glove, masks and etc) waste, by running an experiment in partnership with waste collecting company and private retail chain in Tashkent City. Improving public service delivery in rural areas resulted in establishing Innovation Hot Spots in target regions, which helped to with exploring, solution mapping, and development of the concept for experiments. As part of COVID 19 Task Force, the AccLab helped to address vulnerability challenges caused by the pandemic by 1) helping to digitalize processing aid requests at COVID-19 Help Centers in Namangan city and 2) identifying solutions by running online COVID 19 IT Challenge and working with solutions providers to further improve their solutions.
3 focus areas (environment, employment and good governance) were explored which lead to implementation of 1) Green Aral Sea Initiative that aims at testing alternative financing - crowdfunding - and planting experiments at the dried seabed of the Aral Sea 2) initiation of Innovation of Hot Spots to improve efficiency of public service delivery in rural areas through promoting human centered design and 3) launch of portfolio approach to programming addressing the issue of works / employment to assist with strategic positioning of individual projects and fostering closer interlinkages among them with the aim at achieving large scale impacts.
4 formalized partnerships and 3 informal partnerships. Within the GreenAralSea initiative that pilots crowdfunding for planting trees on the dried seabed of the Aral Sea, AccLab facilitated an establishment of intersectoral partnership with Government agencies (the State Forestry Committee, the Ministry for Innovative Development, the Ministry of Investments and Foreign Trade, and the State Ecology Committee, local authorities) and identification of unusual allies from the private sector representatives, such as Huawei, UPL Limited, Future Enterprise, and academia such as Webster University in Tashkent as well as representatives of civil society - bloggers, prominent artists. The partnership allowed UNDP to strengthen its integrator role and provided a framework to learn and leverage each other’s comparative advantages.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 10 new data sources per year 1.2 9 different type of data sources per year 1.3 50 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 10 innovation methods per Action Plan
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 At least 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network
3.2 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related.
3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network’s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account.
3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1. 12 new data sources: Within Future of Works (FoW) Portfolio Design Process we have applied 1) Desk research, 2) Direct Interviews, 3) Visual Mapping, 4) Collective intelligence, 5) Crowd source; Within the Improving Public Service in Rural Areas we have used: 6) Survey, 7) Observation, 8) Focus group, 9) User journeys, 10) In-depth interviews, 11) Socioeconomic data, 12) Ethnographic data,
1.2 9 different type of data sources are explored: within FOW: 1) Desk research, 2) Direct Interviews, 3) Visual Mapping, 4) Collective intelligence, 5) Crowd source; within Improving Public Service in Rural Areas: 6) Quantitative data from field survey, 7) Qualitative data from observation, focus group and In-depth interviews, 8) Socioeconomic data 9) Ethnographic data
1.3. Target met: 59 new potential solutions are proposed: 1) Data & AI Challenge - Application of AI for the analysis of labour market dynamics; 2) 3 solutions of the Voice AI Challenge Uzbekistan Hackathon; 3) 2 solutions that require cross sectoral collaboration are proposed to the Accelerator Lab for Socio-Economic Reforms 4) 8 recommendations -solutions are proposed for improving public service delivery via mobile units in rural areas 5) 21 preliminary solutions / recommendations were developed as part of Future of Work Portfolio Design process; 6) As part of Staff Retreat Workforce AccLab facilitated group discussions to identify 24 solutions are proposed to improve UNDP attractiveness as a workplace in three subcategories: operations and procedures, programs and partnerships, staff wellbeing;
1.4. Target met: 11 innovation methods - within FOW 1) Collective intelligence, 2) Crowdsourcing, 3) Sensemaking, 4) System thinking, 5) Visual thinking and Mapping and within Public Service delivery: 6) Co-creation, 7) Human Centered Design, 8) Gamification, 9) Personas, 10) Ethnography, 11) Horizon scanning
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1. Target is partially met: 6 posts are published. 3 blogs are published on crowdfunding / 3 reports are published (The Changing Nature of Work: Report on Emerging Signals, Interim Report on Future of Work, Co-Design of Public Services: Quality Assessment of Public Services in Target Regions)
2.2 Target met: Learnings on FoW and IPSD are done in close cooperation with the Ministry of Employment and Labor Relations, Agency of Public Service Delivery
2.3 Target met: Persona’s method is presented to Agency for Public Service Delivery
2.4 Target met: 1) Interim results of portfolio approach for Future of Works were used for two new projects design and as inputs for plans of activities of the project working on employment issues. 2) Survey results on quality of mobile public services in rural areas are used to guide project activities of the UNDP, EU joint project “Improving Public Service Delivery in Rural Areas”
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 Target met: 48 - Lab should interacted at least once a week with another lab, a partner, and the global team. 3.2. Target met: Lab shared insights on running crowdfunding as UNDP, with specific additional blogs on communication and partnership building. 3.3. Done on a regular basis 3.4. Blogs are published on CO website. Regular updates are provided on social media - Facebook, Twitter

The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.
Since the lab was officially launched on October, 2019 new targets were set as:
1. AccLab is Launched and 100 Day Plan developed and implemented; 2. At least 4 initial focus areas are identified; 3. At least one partnership is established;

Target 1. AccLab UNDP in Uzbekistan officially launched on October 7, 2019 in cooperation with the Ministry of Innovative Development. 100 Day plan was developed, which specific targets established for identifying focus areas. The focus areas are identified. The AccLab progress was reported by preparing two blog posts, which received good reaction. Target 2 is achieved: Four initial areas to focus were identified as 1) environmental Issues (including innovations in the Aral Sea region); 2) Youth Employment (with special focus on women, advancing gender equality), 3)Good Governance (including digital government, digital services and more transparent and open decision making) and 4) Promoting Tourism (including ecotourism, aligning efforts to save ecosystems with increasing tourist flows). On Environmental issues, the AccLab developed Aral Sea Greening Initiative, which aims to support the awareness raising about the Aral Sea tragedy and call for action by utilizing alternative financing mechanism (crowdfunding) for planting trees on dried seabed of the Aral Sea.The concept note is shared with key national partners. Target 3 is achieved. AccLab was able to establish both formal and informal partnerships with the national partners and with other UNDP offices. An MOU was signed with the International University of Tourism to work on promoting tourism and SDGs. Partnership was established with AccLab for Socio-Economic Reforms under the Presidents Administration (Government Lab) and Citra Lab of UNDP in Sri-Lanka. As first practical step, representatives of Government Lab and AccLab Uzbekistan visited during Dec 1-6, 2019 Citra Lab in Sri-Lanka.
